resources.string: Pirate boss on board. Send shuttle to rescue.
Ambassador on board. Send shuttle to rescue.
Flying blind. Guide to a station.
Commandeered. Approach in nebula to liberate crew.
Commandeered. Do not approach now, or it will self-destruct. Wait until it enters a nebula, then approach.
Pirate contraband detected. Keep warships away.
Pirate contraband detected. Send a warship to intercept.
Secure data detected. Do not approach.
Secure data detected. Do not permit enemy ships to intercept.
Friendly ship, ready to assist in Deep Strike.
Fighter trap. Do not approach under any circumstances.
Crew taken hostage. Captors demand 900 energy units in ransom.
Onboard computer is malfunctioning. Use EMP to reset it.
Mine trap. Do not approach under any circumstances.
Damages detected. Requesting DamCon team member to conduct repairs.
Out of energy. Requesting 100 units to start moving.
Friendly ship, ready to accept orders.
Friendly ship, en route to a station to deliver a reward for your assistance.

Press Scan to listen for broadcasting servers.
An I/O error has occurred. You have been disconnected from the server.\n\nError: %1$s
An unexpected error has occurred. You have been disconnected from the server.\n\nError: %1$s
An unknown error has occurred while trying to send a packet to the server. There may be a bug in Artemis Agent. Please report the issue on GitHub.\n\nError: %1$s
Artemis Agent only supports Artemis version %1$s or higher. You have been disconnected from the server because its version of Artemis is too old (%2$s).
You have been disconnected from the server because it runs Artemis version %1$s, which is beyond what Artemis Agent currently supports. An update to Artemis Agent is recommended.
You will be disconnected from the server. Confirm exit?

string-array.name: help_contents_about
string-array.item: Written by Jordan Longstaff\n
Special thanks to Robert J. Walker for writing the IAN (Interface for Artemis Networking) library, without which this app could not exist. IAN is available on GitHub. \n
\u00a9 Copyright 2024. All rights reserved.

string-array.name: help_contents_allies
string-array.item: The Allies page shows the statuses of all of the ally ships in the currently running simulation. This includes their shield strengths, direction and range of their locations, side missions, and any other important information.\n

\nLike stations, ally ships communicate their statuses to Artemis Agent through Comms messages. The app automatically sends a status requests to all ally ships when the simulation starts, or if the app connects to a simulation in progress. You can also manually request status by pressing the Hail button.

\nYou can also send commands to an ally ship by pressing the Command button. Commands include turning to a specific direction, attacking the nearest targest, and moving to defend or rendezvous with another station or ally ship. You can also return to the list of ally ships by pressing the Cancel button. Sending a command will return you to the list automatically, unless the "Manually return from commands" setting is turned on.

string-array.name: help_contents_basics
string-array.item: After you have selected your ship, you will be moved to the Game page. This page shows all of the in-game information relevant to the app. Most of it is split among multiple subpages, and you can choose which page is shown using the page selector located below the ship\'s name.\n

\nAside from this information, there are three important controls on this page. The first is the Inventory button, which opens a dialog showing the ship\'s current ordnance stocks and single-seat craft inventory. The second is the Alert button, which toggles the ship\'s \"red alert\" status. The third is the Agent button.\n

In order to use the Agent button, the player ship must acquire secret code cases, which can be used to force an enemy ship to surrender. You can activate one of those secret code cases by pressing the Agent button, and it will remain active for five minutes, or until it is used to make an enemy ship surrender. Only one secret code case may be active at a time.

string-array.name: help_contents_biomechs
string-array.item: The Biomechs page shows the statuses of Biomech ships. Biomechs are generally neutral, but can occasionally turn aggressive and attack something nearby on a whim. If they are attacked, they will turn hostile and attack the player ship or ally ships more often.\n

\nYou can stop a Biomech from moving or attacking anything by freezing it. To freeze a Biomech, simply tap it in the list in the page. The effects of freezing a Biomech will last for only a few minutes; the exact amount of time is determined by the server, but seems to vary slightly and is not communicated to the app, so therefore the app has to estimate it. You can specify the estimated duration in the Settings page. Biomechs can only be frozen a maximum of three times.

string-array.name: help_contents_enemies
string-array.item: The Enemies page is for communications with enemy ships.\n

\nEnemies are hostile and must be defeated as swiftly as possible. Destroying them will suffice, but convincing them to surrender may be preferred. Enemies are identified when they are scanned by the Science officer; however, a second scan is required to obtain intel. Press the Show button to access any intel obtained, as well as the selection of taunts.\n

\nIf an enemy has been sufficiently damaged, they may surrender. To do that, you must send a message asking for a surrender by pressing the Surrender button. Surrender messages are only effective within a certain range; you can configure the app to disable the Surrender button against an enemy that is too far away in the Settings page.

\nTaunts are used to provoke an enemy to attack the player ship, thus luring it away from another target (e.g. a friendly station). Unlike surrenders, taunts are not restricted by distance. However, not all taunts will work; intel obtained by Science includes which of the taunts, dependent on the enemy\'s race, will not work. If that taunt is used, the enemy will ignore it and all subsequent attempts to taunt. The other taunts will work, but generally only once each.

\nThe Settings page has several options to organize the list of enemies. In certain combinations, they can be organized by race, name, distance, and whether or not they\'ve surrendered. You can use the category buttons at the top to quickly scroll through the list. The info displayed in the list for an enemy includes its direction, range, number of successful taunts, and a brief summary of intel about the captain of the enemy ship, which may be one of the following, assuming intel has been obtained (note that this does not include information relevant to taunts):\n
\u2022 Normal: No outstanding characteristics.\n
\u2022 Brave: Less likely to surrender.\n
\u2022 Cowardly: More likely to surrender.\n
\u2022 Duplicitous: Surrenders are not permanent.\n
\u2022 Easily offended: Taunts will work more than once, possibly including ones that normally wouldn\'t work at all.

string-array.name: help_contents_getting_started
string-array.item: Welcome to Artemis Agent! If this is your first time using this app, this tutorial will teach you all you need to know about how to use it.\n

Artemis Agent is a Comms client app designed to be used with Artemis Spaceship Bridge Simulator, developed by Thom Robertson. It will be your assistant in managing side missions, ally ships, stations and more.\n

Before you can use Artemis Agent, you must have an Artemis server running. Open Artemis on your computer and click \"Start Server\". After that, enter the server\'s address into the Address bar at the top of the screen, then touch the Connect button on the right to connect to the server. If the server version is 2.7.0 or greater, you can scan for the presence of the server by pressing the Scan button.\n

\nAfter the app has connected to the server, you must select a ship. The Ships page shows the list of ships to choose from with complete descriptions. Once you select a ship, the app will join that ship as a Comms client.\n

\nIf you press the Home button on your device, Artemis Agent will continue to run in the background. It will continue to receive information via a Comms service and display it in notifications on your device. In general, you can return to Artemis Agent by tapping any of the notifications.\n

If the Artemis server has a mod, you will need to provide a vessel data XML file that matches that of the server. By default, Artemis Agent provides a vessel data file for the stock version of Artemis. If you need to use a different set of vessel data, you can specify the file\'s location in the Settings page. The location that you set will point to either the app\'s internal assets, your device\'s internal storage, or, if applicable, an SD card. Keep in mind that changing this value while the app is connected to a server will automatically terminate the connection.

string-array.name: help_contents_missions
string-array.item: The Missions page shows all currently active side missions. Side missions occur during a running simulation and offer the player an opportunity to acquire various bonuses that last for the remainder of the simulation. These side missions are issued to the Comms officer by an ally ship or station, and include instructions to visit another ship or station before going there to receive a reward. For example, Comms may receive a message like this:\n
\nThis message gives you the following information:\n
1. First, you are being told to go to Y27 (a friendly ship) and rendezvous with it. To rendezvous with a friendly ship means to pass within 500 metres of it.\n
2. Second, after that, you must go to DS3, the sender of the message, and dock there.\n
3. Finally, your reward is that DS3 will double its production speed.\n

The Missions page shows all such missions received in a list, also listing the two destination points in the order that they must be visited, as well as the direction and range to the next one. Although each side mission only offers one reward, the list will be compressed as much as possible by merging entries with the same waypoints. In this way, a single entry in the list may show multiple rewards. If a reward would be received more than once, a \"x2\" or similar multiplier will by shown for that reward. Be sure to pay attention to all rewards shown within a single entry.\n
\nThe rewards you receive for completing side missions are as follows:\n
\u2022 Battery Charge: Your ship will receive some additional energy.\n
\u2022 Extra Coolant: Engineering will receive two additional units of coolant.\n
\u2022 Nuke Torpedoes: Your ship will receive two additional Nuke torpedoes.\n
\u2022 Production Speed: The station that issued the side mission will speed up its production of ordnances.\n
\u2022 Shield Boost: The front and rear shield capacities of your ship will increase.

string-array.name: help_contents_routing
string-array.item: The Routing page shows routing information. Artemis Agent calculates optimized routes to various destinations in the background. When helping ally ships, completing side missions or going to restock ordnances at a station, it is useful to know the order in which to visit them that maximizes rewards while minimizing travel time.\n

\nMultiple types of objectives can be chosen, determining what destinations are shown, what order they are shown in, what the order means, and what information is shown for each that is relevant to the chosen objective. If the Tasks objective is selected, the route shown will be the optimal order of destinations to visit to complete all of the listed objectives, which include both side missions and ally ships in need of help.\n

\nIf the Supplies objective is selected, the route shown will not be a singular route, but rather a list of all stations organized in order of convenience. Convenience in this case means both availability of the desired supplies and the optimal distance calculated to reach the station. You can also select which supplies you want; they can be any type of ordnance or replacement fighters. Your current stock and capacity of each supply is listed when you go to select them. It is recommended that you only choose supplies where your current stock is less than the maximum capacity, as these are supplies that you actually need.\n

Regardless of objective, optimized routes are calculated with certain dangerous objects taken into account. These dangerous objects include black holes, mines and Typhon space monsters. You can disable or adjust these avoidances in Settings. Note that having avoidances taken into consideration means more work for the routing algorithm. Also note that avoidances are not considered for player ships with jump drives. Finally, keep in mind that due to the complex nature of the routing process, an heuristic algorithm is used for efficiency, and therefore the route shown will not necessarily be optimal; it is expected that the Science officer uses the displayed order and cross-references it against their map to determine the optimal route.

string-array.name: help_contents_stations
string-array.item: The Stations page shows information about all of the docking stations in the currently running simulation. This includes shield strengths, direction and range of their locations, production speeds, side missions, stores of replacement fighters, and current ordnance stocks.\n

\nOnly one friendly station at a time is shown, but you can use the selector at the top to choose which one is currently being displayed. You can also press the Closest Station button at the bottom to switch to the station that is closest to the ship\'s current location.\n

Ordnance and replacement fighter stock information is received from the server via Comms messages. Artemis Agent frequently sends messages to each station requesting status updates; the following are examples of circumstances where requests are sent:\n
\u2022 when the simulation starts;\n
\u2022 when the app connects to a simulation in progress;\n
\u2022 when the station finishes building ordnance;\n
\u2022 when the station receives a request to build ordnance of a specific type; or\n
\u2022 when the user manually requests a status update by pressing the Status button.\n

Pressing the Standby button will send a request to the station to stand by for docking. This is recommended when the player ship intends to dock at the station, which is typically done to refuel, recharge shields and restock ordnances, because having a station prepare itself ahead of time makes these recovery operations more efficient.\n

As stations continually build more ordnances, that information is also displayed. At the bottom of the page, you can both see and choose what type of ordnance the station is currently building, along with the amount of time before the station is expected to finish building it. This amount of time is calculated based on the type of ordnance and the station\'s production speed, which varies based on the type of station and increases whenever a Production Speed side mission is completed.\n

In a Deep Strike or Border War simulation, the Stations page is also able to show enemy stations. These stations simply appear in a list and only show shield strength and location information. There is also a separate list that shows all the names of stations that have been destroyed.

resources.string: Vessel data could not be loaded. There is an error in the XML file. The setting has been reverted. Either resolve the error or delete the XML file.\n\nError: %1$s
WARNING: There is an active connection to an Artemis server. The connection will be terminated if you change the vessel data. Proceed?
